0x80070005.solutionHint: Classic permission issue. 1) Run as Administrator. 2) Check NTFS permissions. 3) Check DCOM security settings (dcomcnfg). 4) In SCCM, ensure the 'Network Access Account' is not locked out.

0x80004005.solutionHint: The generic 'Check Engine' light. In Task Sequences, check SMSTS.log for the line *immediately preceding* this error. In Windows Update, usually means corrupted SoftwareDistribution folder.

0x80070002.solutionHint: System cannot find the file. Scripts fail because mapped drives (Z:) do not exist in System Context. Use UNC paths (\\server\share) or %~dp0 variables.

0x80070003.solutionHint: Directory missing. Often happens in Task Sequences when a package fails to download, or the 'Start In' directory is invalid.

0x87d00669.name: CCM_E_APPC_CONTENT_NOT_FOUND
0x87d00669.description: Content cannot be found on Distribution Point.
0x87d00669.solutionHint: 1) Check Boundary Groups (References). 2) Redistribute content. 3) Check CAS.log and LocationServices.log on client.

0x87d00607.name: CCM_E_PROGRESS_TIMEOUT
0x87d00607.solutionHint: Download took too long. 1) Maintenance window is too short. 2) Network is slow. 3) BITS job is stuck (Reset BITS).

0x87d00324.name: CCM_E_INSTALL_TXT_MISMATCH
0x87d00324.solutionHint: The installer finished with Exit Code 0, but SCCM's 'Detection Method' (File/Reg/MSI) could not find the app. Your detection logic is wrong.

0x87d00215.name: CCM_E_ITEM_NOT_FOUND
0x87d00215.solutionHint: Client cache might be corrupt or the policy is missing. Trigger 'Machine Policy Retrieval' and check PolicyAgent.log.

0x87d01106.name: CCM_E_BAD_Digest
0x87d01106.solutionHint: The downloaded file does not match the hash in the console. 1) Update Content on DP. 2) Clear Client Cache (ccmcache). 3) Anti-virus might be modifying the file.

0x800706ba.solutionHint: Firewall blocking Port 135/RPC. 1) Check Windows Firewall. 2) Ensure 'RPC Server' service is running. 3) DNS issues resolving the hostname.

0x80070643.solutionHint: Fatal MSI error. This is a wrapper code. You MUST look at the MSI log (usually %temp%\MSI*.log) to find the real error (often 1603).

0x80070652.solutionHint: Another installation is in progress (Mutex locked). Wait for it to finish or kill 'msiexec.exe'. Common during OSD/Autopilot.

0x80244017.solutionHint: WSUS/Proxy 401/403 Error. Client cannot authenticate to WSUS. Check IIS settings on WSUS or Proxy authentication.

0x8024001e.solutionHint: Windows Update Service is stopping or stopped. Often happens during a reboot cycle or if the service crashes.

0x80244010.solutionHint: Too many round trips to WSUS. This is actually NOT an error; it means 'I have so many updates, I need to talk to the server again'. Just run scan again.

0x80072ee2.solutionHint: Network Timeout. WSUS/Internet is unreachable. Check Proxy, Firewall, or if the WSUS Application Pool is down.

0x80180014.name: MENROLL_E_DEVICE_NOT_SUPPORTED
0x80180014.solutionHint: Enrollment Restriction block. The user is trying to enroll a Personal device but your Intune 'Device Type Restrictions' block 'Personal' platform.

0x8018000a.name: MENROLL_E_DEVICE_ALREADY_ENROLLED
0x8018000a.solutionHint: Device is already enrolled. Delete the old record from Intune/Azure AD or try `dsregcmd /leave`.

0x8007052e.solutionHint: Bad Username or Password. In SCCM, this often means the 'Network Access Account' or 'Domain Join Account' password has expired.

0x80090302.solutionHint: SSL Certificate Error. The client does not trust the Root CA that issued the server's certificate. Deploy the Root CA via GPO.

0x0000007b.name: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE
0x0000007b.solutionHint: Storage Driver Issue. 1) Missing Mass Storage Driver in SCCM Boot Image. 2) Bios set to RAID instead of AHCI (or vice versa).

0x80070070.solutionHint: There is not enough space on the disk. During OSD, ensure the partition size is adequate. Clear ccmcache.

0x8007000d.solutionHint: Data is invalid. Very common in Task Sequences when a Driver Package is corrupt or the BCD (Boot Configuration Data) is messed up.

0xc0000005.solutionHint: Memory Access Violation. Application crashed trying to read protected memory. Often caused by bad RAM, buggy drivers, or buffer overflows.

0x80070422.solutionHint: The service cannot be started because it is disabled. Check services.msc (e.g., Windows Update service).

0x000006be.solutionHint: Remote Procedure Call failed. The remote service crashed or network connection dropped mid-stream.

0x80070035.solutionHint: The network path was not found. 1) DNS resolution failure. 2) SMB blocked by firewall. 3) Target machine is offline.

0x80072f8f.solutionHint: Security/Clock Error. The system clock is significantly different from the server/SSL certificate timestamps. Fix the time/date.

0xC004F074.name: KMS_UNAVAILABLE
0xC004F074.solutionHint: DNS cannot find the KMS SRV record (_vlmcs._tcp). Or firewall blocking port 1688.

0x80070109.solutionHint: The pipe has been ended. Often seen in OSD when the network connection to the Distribution Point is interrupted.

0x8000ffff.solutionHint: Catastrophic failure. Often seen in Store Apps or when Windows component store is heavily corrupted (Run DISM /RestoreHealth).
